[File: third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/resolver.rs] [Function: resolve()] [Path Traversal] Can an attacker provide a malicious root_package_path containing symbolic links or path traversal sequences (../) that bypass directory boundaries and resolve packages from unauthorized filesystem locations? [File: third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/resolver.rs] [Function: resolve()] [Manifest Injection] Can an attacker craft a malicious Move.toml that exploits the parse_package_manifest() parser to inject control characters, cause buffer overflows, or trigger unsafe deserialization leading to code execution? [File: third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/resolver.rs] [Function: resolve()] [DoS Attack] Can an attacker provide a Move.toml with extremely large dependency trees (e.g., 10,000+ packages) that exhaust memory or cause stack overflow during recursive resolve_package calls? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/resolver.rs] [Function: resolve()] [Validation Bypass] Does the function validate that root_package_path actually points to a valid Move package directory before processing, or can an attacker trigger undefined behavior by pointing to arbitrary files/directories? [File: third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/resolver.rs] [Function: resolve()] [Canonical Path Bypass] Can an attacker use case-sensitivity differences in filesystems (e.g., HFS+ vs ext4) to create duplicate package identities with the same canonical path, bypassing the duplicate detection in the resolved BTreeMap? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/resolver.rs] [Function: resolve()] [Dev Mode Confusion] When dev_mode is true, dev dependencies are appended after regular dependencies - can this ordering be exploited to override regular dependencies with malicious dev dependencies through the graph edge ordering? [File: third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/resolver.rs] [Function: resolve()] [Graph Pollution] After resolve() completes, are the graph and resolved structures properly isolated, or can an attacker reuse them to pollute subsequent resolution operations with stale or malicious package references? [File: third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/resolver.rs] [Function: resolve()] [Error Information Leakage] Do error messages from failed resolution operations leak sensitive filesystem paths or internal system information that could aid attackers in reconnaissance? (Low)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-package-resolver/src/resolver.rs] [Function: check_for_cyclic_dependencies()] [Memory Exhaustion] Can an attacker create a graph with multiple large strongly connected components that exhaust memory during the kosaraju_scc computation or when formatting error messages?
